Scenarios.vector: Unauthorized access to brake system components
Scenarios.scenario_desc: An attacker gains access to the undercarriage of a vehicle and physically alters brake lines to reduce brake effectiveness.

Likelihood.Comment: Familiar with the underlying algorithms, protocols, hardware, structures, security behaviour, principles and concepts of security employed, techniques and tools for the definition of new attacks, cryptography, classical attacks for the product type, attack methods, etc.
e.g. as gained from the Internet
Access is required for less than 1 day and number of targets required performing the attack less than 10.
Not readily available to the public because equipment may need to be specially produced, is so specialised that its distribution is restricted, or is very expensive.

Scenarios.scenario_desc: An employee with access to the driving habits data misuses their privileges to sell sensitive information to third parties.

Likelihood.Comment: Familiar with the underlying algorithms, protocols, hardware, structures, security behaviour, principles and concepts of security employed, techniques and tools for the definition of new attacks, cryptography, classical attacks for the product type, attack methods, etc.
e.g. as gained from the Internet
Access is required for less than 1 month and number of targets required to perform the attack less than 100.
Not readily available to the attacker, but acquirable without undue effort. This could include purchase of moderate amounts of equipment or development of more extensive attack scripts or programs.

Scenarios.scenario_desc: An attacker replaces original brake pads with counterfeit, substandard parts which wear out quickly, causing brake failure.

Likelihood.Comment: Familiar with the underlying algorithms, protocols, hardware, structures, security behaviour, principles and concepts of security employed, techniques and tools for the definition of new attacks, cryptography, classical attacks for the product type, attack methods, etc.
e.g. as gained from the Internet
Access is required for less than 1 month and number of targets required to perform the attack less than 100.
Not readily available to the attacker, but acquirable without undue effort. This could include purchase of moderate amounts of equipment or development of more extensive attack scripts or programs.
